title: Can it be said that Paul McCartney is one of the nicest people you'd ever want to meet? - Quora

response.answer_text: It can. A couple of anecdotes I’ve recently heard prove his level of niceness: Alec Baldwin recently DJ’d a Sirius radio piece for their new Beatles channel in which he recalled working with Paul for an episode of Saturday Night Live. Baldwin was hosting and Paul was the guest musician that particular week. A life long rabid Beatles fan, Baldwin remembers being petrified, not knowing how to act or what to say to Sir at their first meeting for the show’s rehearsals. Linda, seeing his hesitation, approached Alec and said, “Just talk to him like he’s a regular guy. That’s what he really wants.” Baldwin thinks, “Yeah, right, like that’s not happening!” Alec said over the course of the week-long project, though, Paul really made an effort to put him at ease and was very likable, down-to-Earth and kind. The leader of the band Elbow commented (on the same Sirius radio channel) that he’d received a congratulatory, approving email from Paul. He’d heard their song ‘Magnificent’ on the radio and liked it. An official nod from Sir Paul? Of course, that meant everything to the band, and they were moved and awestruck that he went out of his way to write them. They saw Paul’s daughter Stella at Glastonbury and mentioned the email to her and how much they appreciated it. She burst into tears, saying, “My dad’s got such a big heart!” Addition: Just watched the long commentary special feature after the restored version of Yellow Submarine narrated by the film’s line producer John Coates. He met and mingled with the Beatles quite a few times during the film’s production in 1967–8. In his very upper crust accent he flatly states that although his musical tastes ran more towards Mozart, all four of the Beatles were nice. They were relaxed, funny - just the kind of guys you’d have hoped they’d be.

WOW so many negative answers here. I guess I will be the one to disagree. I have been in the music business for over 40 years and have met so many great artist unfortunately Paul isn’t one of them at least not yet. Some people you would think would be total divas have turned out to be really nice guys. I can name a few like Jon Bon jovi and Sammy Hagar for example. From everything I’ve seen and heard Paul is supposed to be a very nice guy. I do know people that have met him a few times. Look at it this way, while the other Beatles were living in mansions and part of high society Paul lived on a farm with Linda and his kids. He raised Linda’s daughter like she was his own and brought them all up to be respectful and good people. While living on the farm they were eating dinner (lamb) and were looking out the window at the sheep on the farm and realized that is what they were eating. That made him stop and rethink on how they were eating and became vegetarians. He has for years donated to many charities but never really wanted this to be public knowledge. He did it because he thought it was a great cause not because he wanted recognition. Paul would rather have a 5 minute or longer conversation than sign an autograph because it is more meaningful. I’m sure Paul does realize just how famous and important he is in the world of music but isn’t a diva. While he is a perfectionist and wants things right he is just as hard on himself and maybe harder than he is on everyone else. In the world of music I would say Paul is a pretty nice guy.I know I’d love to work with him.

upvoters.user_id: Isaiah Howansky (イザヤホワンスキー）

response.answer_text: I do not know how anyone can make a judgment based on second-hand information. I don’t know Paul McCartney AT ALL. However, I have watched him and studied him since I was nine in 1964. Here is one story that I know to be true about Paul: John and Paul were huge fans of the Everly Brothers. When they were 15 and 16 respectively, they got to go see an Everly’s concert. They waited at the stage door to meet them. Apparently, the Everly brothers were kind and treated John and Paul well. Paul tells this story often. Now, everytime he gets frustrated by or tired of fans and their demands, he remembers how HE felt as a fan, and it helps him to respond kindly and respectfully. I also refer you to my earlier post regarding Paul and how he treated my Mom at a concert he gave in Columbia, SC, 1992 I think. I won’t go into that again, but you can find it. What he did has remained with her for the almost thirty years since, even though her mind is riddled by Alzheimers. It was that meaningful to her. I hope that someday, my “make a wish” comes true, and I actually get to meet him. He has had a huge impact on my life, and that’s not easy for a 64-year-old man to admit, but it’s true. At that time I hope that my opinion of him doesn’t change. I don’t think it will

I’ve never met Paul McCartney in person, so in my case I claim being subject to a circumstance of irrelevance. Myself, I don’t want to go through life looking for people who are “nice”. I want “authentic”. From any interviews I’ve seen of Paul McCartney, he seems witty and creative with a good edge of self-respect and being aware of the context he’s in (being in the Beatles would be good training for that, since the situations were so extreme). I think if I was at some event he was at and people were hanging out at half time and some such thing, I’d enjoy talking with him because he has that fun sense of humor and creativity and music as I do too. When people are always or obviously “nice”, it can often be because they’re turning themselves OFF so much, or putting on such a phony, slick persona for people, it’s not at all authentic. I’d far prefer to have to figure out how to deal with someone who was authentic with me and had an awkward edge to them, than if they were just “nice”, as if they were a talking welcome mat at a grocery store. I hate being patronized, manipulated, fooled or ripped off, so there’s one answer for ya.

Based on what I’ve learned about Paul, it seems like that is a bit of a tricky question. It sounds like he is a man of immense contradictions. He can at once be incredibly generous, even out of the blue generous for people he doesn’t know, but at the same time can be almost absurdly cheap in how he treats his mates. He paid his Wings mates pretty much scale and kept them in squalor for many of those years. Based on many views of people he has worked with, musically, he can be pushy, overbearing, and unrelenting. He also does not take criticism all that well. He has had some bad press moments through the years that I think have led to some people questioning just how nice/caring of a guy is this…..his comments after Lennon was killed….”It’s a drag” raised a lot of eyebrows, but I didn’t really take it as being mean or uncaring. I mean, what can you say, and why is someone asking him how he feels??? I always got the sense that Paul was a bit of a mystery. I think he tries very hard to project a certain image instead of just being himself. In effect, I think he is a fairly insecure guy…which is strange. But, he has an incredible love for animals, so how bad a guy can he be?? :)

I have never met the guy, but I have been observing him - as a great fan - for almost 50 years. I’ve also read a few books about him. My take is…. you might be right - when you meet Paul McCartney - the image he projects is one of the nicest people in the world. What I mean by that is, I think Paul is acting a lot. Here’s a guy that’s been a superstar all his life. He has NO concept of any other world. I’m not saying he’s insincere or a bad guy, but, I think he puts on a little act when the cameras are rolling…. I have heard nothing about him being a jerk - all I’m saying is - he puts on a little show when you meet him. He’s like Robin Williams was (to a lesser degree) - he’s always ‘on’. I don’t know if that makes any sense… If you ever get to see Broad Street (the movie) - it’s kinda like that. He’s trying to be a normal guy, but, he has no clue on how to be a normal guy - so he ‘acts’ like one :)

no. just watch every picture of paul during their heyday. do you see how his eyes are always wide open like a child seeing something for the first time? this is not his natural look. he just made sure that in every picture taken of him he got this distinct wide eyes expression. he practiced this expression for a very long time. what you’re seeing is a fabricated image, not the person behind it. the person, i’m pretty sure, got the same flaws as every other person on the planet. as a comparison: paul stanley from kiss adopted this. in each and every picture of him with or without the makeup he makes sure he got this wide-open-eyed expression. this paul is the same arrogant prick as the other one who is overly narcissistic. don’t mix up the artificial personas they created with the real persons behind them. if you do you’re in for a huge disappointment the day you find out everything was fake to achieve max income.

Maybe now but he wasnt when he was in the Beatles. Aside from the fact he had Pete Best replaced because “Pete was better looking”, there was another instance involving another drummer, my dad’s friend Jimmy Nichols. Jimmy played 13 dates on the Beatles 1964 tour of New Zealand, Australia and Hong Kong. He, my dad and a few of their friends met up with Jimmy afterwards. Jimmy said it was one of his worst experiences as a musician. To begin with, once he was told he got the job he was instructed that he had to play “like Ringo.” Jimmy told them he was a classically trained drummer and couldnt switch his style. He also stated that the Beatles were the most arrogant S.O.B.s he’s ever had the misfortune of playing with. Outside of TV interviews and rehearsals the rest of the band wouldn't speak to him. When asked if he’d ever play with them again, Jimmy replied with “Never.”

I think we should always be mindful that the public image of celebrities is not necessarily their true nature. Let’s be real here, famous people are like PR creations, their character is carefully tailored, and very often professionally designed. How they appear in public, their political ideas, who they support, what products they endorse, what clothing, car brand, type of housing they have - it is all a careful project. The true nature of people is never what you see each day-we each have a ‘private self’ that we carefully conceal. It is not just ‘psychopaths’ that have a ‘Mask’, it is a human trait. So, who knows, Mr McCartney could be a darling, he might be sweet as Cherry pie to people and those he loves; then again he might be irritable, arrogant, impatient…we shall never truly know, and that is the way of things.

I’ve never met Paul. I wouldn’t know what to say if I did. But I do watch a lot of his interviews, documentaries and appearances on talk shows. There is one thing I’ve noticed about Paul. He will answer any question. Never have I seen say that’s personal or that’s crossing the line. And there was one doc where he was walking in New York City. He gets in his car and George the driver takes off. But before they can get very far a fan starts chasing. Paul recognizes him as a seller on Ebay. In other words, he gets stuff autographed then sells it. So Paul tells George to speed up and then he says wait. George stops and Paul signs whatever the guy wants signed. Ringo wont even do that. So I think deep down he is probably a nice guy. Yeah he is protected. He should be.

I’ve never met Paul. I can tell you that people I know who have all seem to have the same consensus: “Pleasantly insincere” - even Ringo and George have said that in the past (google it) - even PAUL has said that (again … google it) Put yourself in Paul’s shoes - he is so “famous” that people over-react when they meet him and don’t treat him like a normal person - what is he supposed to do? Just enjoy his music. I like most of it and I don’t care if I ever meet him or if he’s “nice” or not. Fame is a dog from hell.
Paul McCartney is soft-spoken, politically correct, optimistic, and friendly. But on the same time he is rather hard to deal with because Paul is rather demanding, bossy, and stubborn.

I met him once in the Top Of The Pops studio in 1992 during the recording of the Christmas programme - can’t remember what the song was now. I found him to be a nice guy and his daughter Mary was lovely. I seem to remember that Ringo Starr’s daughter Lee was there with Mary…

He’s the intelligent Beatle. He knows he’s good looking and he plays that card heavily. He knows he is witty and naturally being a musical genius he carries around a pretty big ego as well. I can’t believe that Lennon always managed to keep him from taking over. That’s my take on him.

I am pretty sure the man is full of himself. He loves to be seen as very nice, but he is really a megalomaniac (John Lennon’s words). John Lennon also said: ‘everybody who reaches the top is a bastard, including myself.’ You can be sure this applies to Paul Mccartney as well.

He came through Oklahoma City while he and his wife were doing a Route 66 car trip. Everyone he came into contact with remarked on how gracious and kind he was to them. I heard no one say a bad word about either Paul or his wife.

“Can it be said that Paul McCartney is one of the nicest people you'd ever want to meet?” It can be said, but it isn’t true. Paul McCartney is a nice guy but at the same time he has also been one of the biggest bastards on Earth. Just like his friend John Lennon.
No. It can’t be said because until you have met him you will not know whether he is nice or an absolute arse.
Paul has always been My Favourite BEATLE and to see what a great guy he is and how naturally Funny just watch him on James Cordon's Carpool Karaoke.
He’s a professional Nice Guy. If you scratch behind the image, you’ll find a Little Englander
You just did. So I guess the answer is yes, it can be said.
